title: Doing Good by Doing Well: Capitalism, Humanitarianism and International Development
abstractText:
As policy makers, practitioners and journalists debate the role of the private sector in a post-2015 agenda for international development this seminar series will bring them together with leading academics in anthropology, development studies and business/management to critically examine market based approaches to development. Taking its cue from the mantra of global social enterprise - that it is possible to 'do good by doing well' - this seminar series explores the business models that are transforming arenas of international development practice.

Through international conferences, UK practitioner roundtables, and post-graduate advanced seminars this seminar series will address key questions about the workings, outcomes, models and claims and impacts of social entrepreneurship.Key questions include:

  • How is social enterprise mobilising people, driving policies, attracting finance and shaping politics at national and international levels?
  • How are goods and technologies that are being marketed to the global poor endowed with moral power and the capacity to bring development benefits?
  • How is the social impact of these goods being measured by governments, business or international organisations and how might participant perspectives suggest different measures for development outcomes?
  • How does an ethic of humanitarian capitalism reflect broader social concerns and economic tensions?
